reviewText: I would love to buy my own copy. Have watched it twice now and loved it each time. But cost is just too high for me to get my own copy. Hopefully the prices will come down on this one. Its a shame people are pricing it so high. Maybe it could be enjoyed by more people if they didn't.

reviewerName: Michael B. Druxman "A Good Story is a Terribl...
reviewText: ALL THAT HEAVEN ALLOWS is a perfect example of the glossily beautiful “women’s movies” that producer Ross Hunter turned out for Universal during the 1950s.  Like this 1955 release, Douglas Sirk directed many of these romantic melodramas.Jane Wyman and Rock Hudson, who had co-starred a year earlier in the Hunter/Sirk filming of MAGNIFICENT OBSESSION, also headline this effort, which deals with a well-off widow (Wyman), who falls in love with her earthy, much younger gardener (Hudson).  Naturally, her college-age children and the conservative local community react negatively to the relationship.ALL THAT HEAVEN ALLOWS is a touching tale, written by Peg Fenwick from a story by Edna L. Lee and Harry Lee, that is, in many ways, just as viable today as it was back in 1955.  The performances are fine, but what is most striking about the picture is the vibrant use of color by cinematographer Russell Metty that delicately enhances film’s emotional tones.  Sadly, they don’t make movies that look this stunning any more.The supporting cast includes Agnes Moorehead, Conrad Nagel, Virginia Grey, William Reynolds, Gloria Talbott, Charles Drake and, in a one-scene unbilled role, David Janssen.The 3-disc (1 Blu-Ray/2 DVD) set from The Criterion Collection contains several extras, including a 2007 interview with actor William Reynolds, who plays Wyman’s son in the movie, excerpts from a 1979 and a 1982 documentary  about Douglas Sirk that contain interviews with the director, audio commentary featuring film scholars John Mercer and Tamar Jeffers-McDonald and more.  There is also the usual Criterion booklet, which has an essay by film scholar Laura Mulvey and an excerpt from an essay about Sirk, written by filmmaker Rainer Werner Fassbinder. Michael B. Druxman

reviewText: Douglas Sirk's pluperfect example of the glossy, frothy women's weepy gets an A-grade transfer from Criterion with memorable extras. Just the sort of grand way to spend a rainy/snowy afternoon. Great stuff!

reviewText: From Douglas Sirk, the granddaddy of soaps, comes the triumph All That Heaven Allows, a small-town melodrama of forbidden lovers in a world that will not accept them.This movie is so impressive largely because it handles such sappy material with genuine dignity and humanity. The basic premise has Jane Wyman as an upper-middle class widow, falling in love with her gardener Rock Hudson. They come from two different worlds - hers of country clubs and garden parties, his of cabins and nature. (His background and interests barely get fleshed out, but who cares?)The strong performances truly elevate the slim plot, making us believe their romance and desperation to a far greater level than we probably should. With each disapproval from neighbors and family, the impact and toll it takes on their love are truly painful to withstand.This film resonates so well also because it is still relevant; the strong socioeconomic contrast that nearly keeps them apart is just as real today, arguably even more so given the ever-rising divorce rates.We also get some classic Sirkian phallic symbols - from Rock Hudson wielding a rifle at waist level to his ascending blanketed knee upon Jane Wyman’s arrival in a pivotal scene, Sirk inserts plenty of sex into an (explicitly) sexless film.In addition to these tongue-in-cheek visual cues, though, Sirk also creates powerful imagery to convey Wyman’s sense of entrapment. In one memorable scene, her children (who have just expressed their intolerance of her new romance) give her a new TV set, placing it in an open space between a chair and the fireplace. This contraption, referenced earlier to “keep housewives busy” during the day, is spatially trapping her in her home - even further driven as the camera zooms into the TV’s reflection of Jane Wyman staring sadly into the screen.The strong performances and gorgeous technicolor visuals contribute to a masterwork that far surpasses its predecessor Magnificent Obsession and grazes the brilliance of Written on the Wind.
Title: N/A
